content.value: A database is a structured system used to store, manage, and retrieve data efficiently. On Linux, we commonly install and manage database servers like MySQL/MariaDB or PostgreSQL.
Databases run as services, accept client connections, and allow commands through a CLI or GUI tools. Linux provides easy management of users, permissions, and backups from the terminal.

value: Popular relational DB for web apps (WordPress, PHP, LAMP)
Advanced relational DB with powerful features & performance
Lightweight DB stored in a single file

content.value: MySQL/MariaDB = beginners & websites | PostgreSQL = enterprise & big systems
Databases are installed using package managers and controlled using systemctl, just like web servers.

content.command:
sudo systemctl start mysql
sudo systemctl enable mysql
content.description: Start and enable MySQL service at boot.

content.command:
sudo systemctl start postgresql
sudo systemctl enable postgresql
content.description: Start and enable PostgreSQL service at boot.

content.value: If service won't start → check logs with: sudo journalctl -u mysql
